awd_titl_txt: AISES Convening on Computer Science Research Infrastructure for Native-Serving Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Given the underrepresentation of Native students, professionals, and faculty in the field of computer science (CS), American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) believes now is a critical time to focus on strengthening CS research infrastructure of Native-serving institutions to move the needle on broadening participation. To this end, AISES will develop and host the Convening on Computer Science Research Infrastructure for Native-Serving Institutions, gathering faculty from a diverse set of Native-serving institutions to understand the issues they face, securing funding, and engaging students in CS research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) hosted the Convening on Computer Science Research Infrastructure for Native-Serving Institutions from September 27-28, 2019, in Chicago, IL. Faculty from Native-serving institutions, AISES representatives, NSF representatives, and other CS research stakeholders attending the convening. The purpose of the convening was to understand how to improve CS research infrastructure at Native-serving institutions across the country. The convening resulted in several key insights including:

  • A significant need for mainstream 4-year institutions to meaningfully collaborate with 2-year institutions and tribal colleges and universities to successfully conduct CS research and engage Native students/communities.
  • Four-year, R1 institutions were most interested in understanding how to recruit and retain Native students in CS courses and research.
  • Need to engage in interdisciplinary research to make Computer Science research more relevant to Native students and Native-serving institutions.
  • Two-year and TCUs cited lack of institutional support for grant writing and research infrastructure as barriers to securing research funding and conducting research.
  • Two-year and TCU faculty were also unfamiliar with developing and conducting CS research projects.
  • Need to effectively communicate benefit and relevance of CS research to Native students and teaching faculty at two-year colleges and TCUs.
  • Faculty at all institutions cited typical resource limitations: time, sustainable funding, facilities, qualified faculty, access to data, and prepared undergraduate and graduate students to support research efforts.

Based on these findings, AISES recommended future funding opportunities to support collaboration between Native-serving two-year institutions and four-year, research institutions to engage two-year institutions in CS research, allowing for exposure to and engagement in research as two-year institutions build capacity to develop their own research programs. These collaborations would allow non-research faculty opportunities to engage in research and develop their own research programs with support from more experienced researchers while also engaging Native students in CS research. Ultimately, the findings and recommendations from the convening provided critical feedback necessary for the NSF to better support research at Native-serving institutions, particularly those with minimal research infrastructure. The long-term goal of the conversations initiated at the convening is to engage Native students and communities in computer science research by starting and strengthening CS research conducted at Native-serving institutions.

 


Last Modified: 09/16/2021
Modified by: Kathy Deerinwater
